image.altText: A close up portrait of a teenage boy with glasses, standing with trees and wattle behind him. He is looking to the side.

items.synopsis: Thousands of babies who've been exposed to their mother's drug use are born in Australia every year. Help is difficult to find.

title.children: Bryce is living with the consequences of his mum's drug use during pregnancy

image.altText: Side by side photos of business logos for accounting firms Deloitte, PwC, KPMG and EY

items.synopsis: The infiltration of EY, Deloitte, KPMG and PwC in government departments has been well documented. What is less well known is their role in the private sector, where experts fear a sleeper issue could trigger a corporate collapse, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How a sleeper issue inside the big four accounting giants could topple the economy

image.altText: A composite of Jeremy Rockliff sitting in the house of assembly folding his arms and Rebecca White looking off.

items.synopsis: Tasmania is the only state or territory without its own political donation legislation, so only donors who contribute more than $14,500 are ever revealed. That could be about to change, writes Adam Holmes.

title.children: Very few Tasmanian political donations are known — but they could soon be brought into the public eye

image.altText: A woman with black glasses up against a blue wall

items.synopsis: Mary-Louise McLaws, who was an epidemiologist at UNSW Sydney for more than 35 years and shared crucial information during the pandemic, has died after a long illness, her family has announced.

title.children: Mary-Louise McLaws, renowned epidemiologist who helped guide Australia through the pandemic, dies aged 70

image.altText: A skiier in a yellow jacket skis down a steep slope

items.synopsis: Discretionary spending is money you don't need to spend to keep yourself fed, housed and clothed. What's happening at alpine resorts — remote and relatively expensive — tells us about an important shift in the Australian economy.

title.children: Australians are reducing their spending as the cost of living soars. But that doesn't mean they're making rational choices

image.altText: A composite image of Sam Kerr and Michele Bullock

items.synopsis: From the Matildas to some of the most important appointments in the country, Australian women are beginning to receive the acknowledgement and opportunities at the top of their fields that unquestionably until now have been denied, writes John Lyons.

title.children: What Sam Kerr and new RBA governor Michele Bullock have in common

image.altText: A youth walks down a street in Roebourne alongside a metal fence.

items.synopsis: Once synonymous with alcohol abuse and social malaise, Roebourne is a town in recovery. But traditional owners lament what they say are the divisions caused by a mining giant.

title.children: 'Triumph and tragedy' of town divided in fight against mining giant

image.altText: The tail of a Jetstar aircraft showing its name an livery

items.synopsis: The airline confirms it has cancelled flights between Darwin and Denpasar for three weeks in October due to runway upgrades at Darwin Airport.

title.children: 'Disappointing and frustrating': Jetstar cancels October flights between Darwin and Bali

image.altText: Scott Brunton with a horse in a stable.

items.synopsis: One of Tasmania's largest thoroughbred training stables says it is "stunned" to be put into administration, saying a five-year payment plan totalling about $1 million was rejected by the ATO.

title.children: 'We are stunned': Top Tasmanian thoroughbred stable goes into administration owing tax office

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a t-shirt that says "love" before and after breast reduction surgery.

items.synopsis: Surgery to decrease bra cup sizes is on the increase in Australia. Helen Stojanovski just wishes she'd booked her surgery sooner.

title.children: The number of Aussies getting breast reductions has tripled in three years. Helen is one of them

image.altText: Side by side images of a resort town. Left it is green and has boats in the water, on the right brown and burned down, no boats.

items.synopsis: Aerial footage and satellite images show how devastating the fires that engulfed the Hawaiian island of Maui have been, as crews continue searching for survivors.

title.children: Lahaina was once a lush green resort town, it's now been reduced to ash and rubble

image.altText: Greg Stewart with rail bug

items.synopsis: The railway group volunteer has built a set of rail bugs from scratch, hoping they provide a lifeline for his railway group.

title.children: Greg's pedal-powered plan to get tourism back on track in Tasmania's north-east

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The ASX is lower as the big banks and major miners weigh on the major indices, despite results-induced bounces for several companies. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX slips on banks, despite results bounce for JB Hi-Fi, Carsales

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're wondering why Hong Kong's Hang Seng share index is down so much more than other markets, and potentially one reason why the ASX took a bit of a dip around the middle of the day, financial news service Reuters has some news on a major Chinese developer : Shares of China's Country Garden plunged more than 12% on Monday morning after the real estate company suspended trading in 11 of its onshore bonds from Monday. The stock hit a new low of HK$0.86, following reports on Friday the company was heading for a debt restructuring that added to concerns about the deteriorating outlook in the property sector. Markets are jittery as more developers default on bond payments amid no signs of stronger support measures from Beijing. Country Garden last week missed payments of two dollar bond coupons due on Aug. 6 totalling $22.5 million, confirming market fears that the developer was slipping into repayment troubles.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hong Kong listed Country Garden suspends bond trading, shares slump

Hong Kong's Hang Seng
share index is down so much more than other markets, and potentially one reason why the ASX took a bit of a dip around the middle of the day, financial news service
Reuters has some news on a major Chinese developer
Shares of China's Country Garden plunged more than 12%
on Monday morning after the real estate company
suspended trading in 11 of its onshore bonds
from Monday.
The stock hit a new low of HK$0.86, following reports on Friday the company was heading for a debt restructuring that added to concerns about the deteriorating outlook in the property sector.
Markets are jittery as more developers default on bond payments amid no signs of stronger support measures from Beijing.
Country Garden last week missed payments of two dollar bond coupons due on Aug. 6 totalling $22.5 million
, confirming market fears that the developer was slipping into repayment troubles.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is slipping further into the red around the middle of the trading session, as Asian markets post early falls. Havin started off just 0.2%, the ASX 200 index is now 0.8% lower at 7,280. The Australian dollar is also weaker, approaching its lowest level since November last year at 64.6 US cents. The big banks and miners are a major drag on the share market, having deepened their losses during the morning. The big four banks are down between 0.8-1.1% and the two major miners, BHP and Rio, are both off close to 1.5%. Energy was the brightest spot on the market, up 0.8% as oil prices remained near recent highs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX deepens losses at midday, dollar approaches nine-month low

BHP and Rio, are both off close to 1.5%
Energy was the brightest spot on the market, up 0.8% as oil prices remained near recent highs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Perhaps, like me, you've noticed a recent steep rise in fuel prices at the petrol/diesel pump? That's largely because oil prices have rebounded over the past month or so. CBA commodity analyst Vivek Dhar explains why. "The resiliency of global oil demand combined with OPEC+ oil supply cuts has already tightened oil markets," he explains. " Brent futures rose above $US88/bbl in intra day trading on 10 August, but has since eased below $US87/bbl. Futures were as low as $US72/bbl on 27 June. " Saudi Arabia's pledge to voluntarily cut 1mb/d (~1% of global supply) in Q3 2023 has played a crucial role in driving oil prices higher. The IEA [International Energy Agency] noted that Saudi Arabia's oil output fell by 0.95mb/d last month. " Russia has also committed to reduce oil exports from August (0.5mb/d cut in August and a 0.3mb/d cut in September). The IEA reported that Russia's crude oil exports fell 0.2mb/d to 4.6mb/d in July, marking the lowest level since December 2022." The resiliency in demand is expected to continue, at least in the short term, with the IEA upping its forecasts for this year and holding them steady for next. "The IEA now anticipate that global oil demand will grow 2.2% in 2023 (previously 2.1%), before slowing to 1% (previously 1.1%) next year," writes Dhar. "The slight upgrade to the IEA's oil demand forecast for 2023 is broadly consistent with global oil demand rising to record highs of 103mb/d in June. Oil demand has strengthened because of "strong summer air travel, increased oil use in power generation and surging petrochemical activity." The IEA noted that global oil demand in August may eclipse June levels. "The fall in global oil demand growth next year is tied primarily to increased fuel efficiency, higher uptake of electric vehicles (EVs) and reduced demand growth from China. "Increased fuel efficiency and the uptake of EVs are expected to suppress global oil demand in later years too. In June, the IEA released a view on oil demand trends to 2028. Oil demand was expected to grow ~1% in 2025, just like in 2024, before slowing to ~0.4% by 2028."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil demand expected to rise, keeping prices above recent lows

children.content: Perhaps, like me, you've noticed a recent steep rise in fuel prices at the petrol/diesel pump?
That's largely because
oil prices have rebounded
over the past month or so.
CBA commodity analyst Vivek Dhar
explains why.
"The resiliency of global oil demand combined with OPEC+ oil supply cuts has already tightened oil markets," he explains.
Brent futures rose above $US88/bbl in intra day trading on 10 August
, but has since eased below $US87/bbl.
Futures were as low as $US72/bbl on 27 June
Saudi Arabia's pledge to voluntarily cut 1mb/d (~1% of global supply)
in Q3 2023 has played a crucial role in driving oil prices higher. The IEA [International Energy Agency] noted that Saudi Arabia's oil output fell by 0.95mb/d last month.
Russia has also committed to reduce oil exports from August
(0.5mb/d cut in August and a 0.3mb/d cut in September). The IEA reported that Russia's crude oil exports fell 0.2mb/d to 4.6mb/d in July, marking the lowest level since December 2022."
The resiliency in demand is expected to continue, at least in the short term, with the IEA upping its forecasts for this year and holding them steady for next.
"The IEA now anticipate that
global oil demand will grow 2.2% in 2023
(previously 2.1%), before slowing to 1% (previously 1.1%) next year," writes Dhar.

props.alt: China is expected to account for the majority of oil demand growth next year

children.content: China is expected to account for the majority of oil demand growth next year
(IEA/CBA)
"The slight upgrade to the IEA's oil demand forecast for 2023 is broadly consistent with
global oil demand rising to record highs of 103mb/d in June

. Oil demand has strengthened because of "strong summer air travel, increased oil use in power generation and surging petrochemical activity." The IEA noted that global oil demand in August may eclipse June levels.
"The fall in global oil demand growth next year is tied primarily to increased fuel efficiency, higher uptake of electric vehicles (EVs) and reduced demand growth from China.

"Increased fuel efficiency and the uptake of EVs are expected to suppress global oil demand in later years too. In June, the IEA released a view on oil demand trends to 2028. Oil demand was expected to grow ~1% in 2025, just like in 2024, before slowing to ~0.4% by 2028."

image.altText: Reza berati

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old was killed in riots at the Australian government's offshore detention centre at Manus Island in 2014.

title.children: Murdered Iranian asylum seeker Reza Berati's parents reach settlement with government, security firm

image.altText: Nicole Hammat holds a framed photograph of her son Khye smiling

items.synopsis: After seeing how quickly her son Khye succumbed to the disease, Nicole Hammat wants young people to be more aware of meningococcal and is pleading for the B strain vaccine to be made accessible to more people.

title.children: Mother's plea for meningococcal B vaccine to be made more accessible as cases continue to rise

image.altText: A close-up shot of a pallet of cardboard boxes being pulled by a red and black pallet jack.

items.synopsis: WA authorities discover 300,000 vapes in a Perth warehouse, along with more than 10 tonnes of illegal prescription drugs and "nangs",  in what they say is the biggest-ever bust of its kind in Australia.

title.children: More than 25 tonnes of vapes and 'nangs' found hidden in record seizure

image.altText: Catriona Jackson speaks.

items.synopsis: Leaders at a major Australian university say they have deep concerns around the management of the sector's peak body, Universities Australia (UA).

title.children: Future of Universities Australia head under question over handling of sexual violence concerns

image.altText: A generic photo of a green seedling in dirt in an egg carton, with other little seedlings around it.

items.synopsis: We heard from more than 1,000 of you who shared the little, and big, things you do to reduce your waste footprint. There were plenty of new and novel ideas for reusing and recycling, so we're tapping into the brains trust.

title.children: We asked for your waste-busting tips. Here are some of your suggestions

image.altText: man with weights in gym

items.synopsis: An increasing demand for steroids in young men has been linked to a growing uptake for a needle and syringe exchange program, leading to calls for more education on the side effects.

title.children: 'You're just relying on the next gym bro': Young men desperate for safe steroid advice

image.altText: A meteor with a long white tail in the night sky.

items.synopsis: The annual Perseid meteor shower reached its peak this weekend, sending bright trails of light streaking across the night sky around the world.

title.children: Spectacular meteor shower lights up skies across the world

image.altText: A lady with a red face following chemo treatment.

items.synopsis: A Greens senator's experience with skin cancer prompts a warning about cumulative sun exposure as skin cancer rates rise, despite the success of the Slip Slop Slap campaign for those born after 1980.

title.children: Melanoma rates dropping for younger people in Queensland, but skin cancer still on the rise

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann looks serious, sitting wearing his glasses against a blurred background.

items.synopsis: The former Liberal Party adviser says his life is "stuffed" and he may never work again after his high-profile rape trial was abandoned.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann says he will seek 'millions' of dollars after inquiry finds prosecution was flawed

image.altText: A man holds two green apples in his hands

items.synopsis: While inflation on food has gone down according to stats from the Australian Bureau of Statistics June 2023 report, prices for things like dairy and bread remain sky high.

title.children: Food prices have risen 7.5 per cent in the last year. Here's what that looks like at the check-out

image.altText: a ranger in high viz green suit lights a fire next to a dirt road

items.synopsis: Facing down another potentially dangerous bushfire season, firefighters are warning there is no room for complacency — those at risk need to have a plan.

title.children: The three questions firefighters want you to answer before the next bushfire sparks

image.altText: Australia players look pained after a penalty miss at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: With just four days to recover from their draining penalty shootout win over France, the Matildas are focused on getting their bodies and minds right to face England, rather than drilling tactics.

title.children: Sleeping, eating and hydrating: Four-day turnaround before World Cup semi has Matildas in recovery mode

image.altText: fruits and vegetables in plastic bags

items.synopsis: Nanocellulose is a tiny fibre with huge potential. It can be created from food waste and transformed into biodegradable packaging.

title.children: Packaging made from food waste could save millions of tonnes of produce from landfill

image.altText: A man and woman smile for the camera.

items.synopsis: Ian Wilkinson's family says he remains in a critical but stable condition, thanking medical teams and the public for their support after he fell ill in the Victorian town of Leongatha.

title.children: Family of man hospitalised after suspected mushroom poisoning thanks medical staff, public for support

image.altText: Two young boys stand out the front of the youth centre.

items.synopsis: In Tennant Creek, where shopfronts are graffitied or boarded up, the town's youth centre stands out as shiny and new — but it's never opened its doors.

title.children: These kids say a youth centre will make a big difference to their lives. One sits empty in their town

image.altText: A police officer crouching down to take a photo of a wrecked car

items.synopsis: If you came across a traffic crash, could you be the difference between life and death?

title.children: Knowing basic first aid could help reduce the road toll —  so should the qualification be part of getting a licence?

image.altText: Copy of Thumbnail

items.synopsis: China's president Xi has not visited the places devastated by the two weeks of torrential rain and flooding, which has angered and confused many people.

title.children: While floods ravage northern China, people are wondering — where is President Xi Jinping?

image.altText: A woman wearing an orange polka dot top writes in a notebook in front of a desktop computer

items.synopsis: Can an employer, having first directed you to work from home, now turn around and mandate you don't? Giuseppe Carabetta explains your legal rights.

title.children: Can your employer force you back to the office? Here's what the law says

image.altText: A grey navy patrol ship with a bridge in the background.

items.synopsis: Firing on a merchant vessel is expected to ratchet up already acute concerns among shipowners, insurers and commodity traders about the potential dangers of getting ensnared in the Black Sea.

title.children: Russia fires warnings shots on cargo ship in Black Sea for first time since collapse of UN-brokered grain deal

image.altText: Man with red background

items.synopsis: Hip hop helps to create cultural identity and brings together communities, but is still widely seen as an American and African American art form.

title.children: Fifty years on, the Australian hip hop industry still gets a bad rap

image.altText: Woman drinks from her water bottle looking up towards sun in blue sky.

items.synopsis: If the northern hemisphere's deadly heatwave is anything to go by, Australia could be in for its own long, hot summer.

title.children: More heatwaves are on the horizon and that means more people in hospital
